verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you touch the man with the discharge, you must wash your clothes and bathe yourself in water, and you will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the man spits on you, you must wash your clothes and bathe yourself in water, and you will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any saddle blanket on which the man rides will be ceremonially unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you touch anything that was under the man, you will be unclean until evening. You must wash your clothes and bathe yourself in water, and you will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the man touches you without first rinsing his hands, you must wash your clothes and bathe yourself in water, and you will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any clay pot the man touches must be broken, and any wooden utensil he touches must be rinsed with water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When the man with the discharge is healed, he must count off seven days for the period of purification. Then he must wash his clothes and bathe himself in fresh water, and he will be ceremonially clean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the eighth day he must get two turtledoves or two young pigeons and come before the Lord at the entrance of the Tabernacle and give his offerings to the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest will offer one bird for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. Through this process, the priest will purify the man before the Lord for his discharge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Whenever a man has an emission of semen, he must bathe his entire body in water, and he will remain ceremonially unclean until the next evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any clothing or leather with semen on it must be washed in water, and it will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a man and a woman have sexual intercourse, they must each bathe in water, and they will remain unclean until the next evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Whenever a woman has her menstrual period, she will be ceremonially unclean for seven days. Anyone who touches her during that time will be unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anything on which the woman lies or sits during the time of her period will be unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any of you touch her bed, you must wash your clothes and bathe yourself in water, and you will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you touch any object she has sat on, you must wash your clothes and bathe yourself in water, and you will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This includes her bed or any other object she has sat on; you will be unclean until evening if you touch it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man has sexual intercourse with her and her blood touches him, her menstrual impurity will be transmitted to him. He will remain unclean for seven days, and any bed on which he lies will be unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a woman has a flow of blood for many days that is unrelated to her menstrual period, or if the blood continues beyond the normal period, she is ceremonially unclean. As during her menstrual period, the woman will be unclean as long as the discharge continues.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any bed she lies on and any object she sits on during that time will be unclean, just as during her normal menstrual period.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any of you touch these things, you will be ceremonially unclean. You must wash your clothes and bathe yourself in water, and you will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When the woman’s bleeding stops, she must count off seven days. Then she will be ceremonially clean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the eighth day she must bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons and present them to the priest at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest will offer one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering. Through this process, the priest will purify her before the Lord for the ceremonial impurity caused by her bleeding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is how you will guard the people of Israel from ceremonial uncleanness. Otherwise they would die, for their impurity would defile my Tabernacle that stands among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the instructions for dealing with anyone who has a bodily discharge—a man who is unclean because of an emission of semen
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or a woman during her menstrual period. It applies to any man or woman who has a bodily discharge, and to a man who has sexual intercourse with a woman who is ceremonially unclean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses after the death of Aaron’s two sons, who died after they entered the Lord’s presence and burned the wrong kind of fire before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Warn your brother, Aaron, not to enter the Most Holy Place behind the inner curtain whenever he chooses; if he does, he will die. For the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement—is there, and I myself am present in the cloud above the atonement cover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When Aaron enters the sanctuary area, he must follow these instructions fully. He must bring a young bull for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He must put on his linen tunic and the linen undergarments worn next to his body. He must tie the linen sash around his waist and put the linen turban on his head. These are sacred garments, so he must bathe himself in water before he puts them on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron must take from the community of Israel two male goats for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Aaron will present his own bull as a sin offering to purify himself and his family, making them right with the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he must take the two male goats and present them to the Lord at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is to cast sacred lots to determine which goat will be reserved as an offering to the Lord and which will carry the sins of the people to the wilderness of Azazel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron will then present as a sin offering the goat chosen by lot for the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other goat, the scapegoat chosen by lot to be sent away, will be kept alive, standing before the Lord. When it is sent away to Azazel in the wilderness, the people will be purified and made right with the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Aaron will present his own bull as a sin offering to purify himself and his family, making them right with the Lord. After he has slaughtered the bull as a sin offering,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he will fill an incense burner with burning coals from the altar that stands before the Lord. Then he will take two handfuls of fragrant powdered incense and will carry the burner and the incense behind the inner curtain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There in the Lord’s presence he will put the incense on the burning coals so that a cloud of incense will rise over the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement—that rests on the Ark of the Covenant. If he follows these instructions, he will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he must take some of the blood of the bull, dip his finger in it, and sprinkle it on the east side of the atonement cover. He must sprinkle blood seven times with his finger in front of the atonement cover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then Aaron must slaughter the first goat as a sin offering for the people and carry its blood behind the inner curtain. There he will sprinkle the goat’s blood over the atonement cover and in front of it, just as he did with the bull’s blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Through this process, he will purify the Most Holy Place, and he will do the same for the entire Tabernacle, because of the defiling sin and rebellion of the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one else is allowed inside the Tabernacle when Aaron enters it for the purification ceremony in the Most Holy Place. No one may enter until he comes out again after purifying himself, his family, and all the congregation of Israel, making them right with the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then Aaron will come out to purify the altar that stands before the Lord. He will do this by taking some of the blood from the bull and the goat and putting it on each of the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he must sprinkle the blood with his finger seven times over the altar. In this way, he will cleanse it from Israel’s defilement and make it holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When Aaron has finished purifying the Most Holy Place and the Tabernacle and the altar, he must present the live goat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will lay both of his hands on the goat’s head and confess over it all the wickedness, rebellion, and sins of the people of Israel. In this way, he will transfer the people’s sins to the head of the goat. Then a man specially chosen for the task will drive the goat into the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the goat goes into the wilderness, it will carry all the people’s sins upon itself into a desolate land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When Aaron goes back into the Tabernacle, he must take off the linen garments he was wearing when he entered the Most Holy Place, and he must leave the garments there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he must bathe himself with water in a sacred place, put on his regular garments, and go out to sacrifice a burnt offering for himself and a burnt offering for the people. Through this process, he will purify himself and the people, making them right with the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He must then burn all the fat of the sin offering on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The man chosen to drive the scapegoat into the wilderness of Azazel must wash his clothes and bathe himself in water. Then he may return to the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The bull and the goat presented as sin offerings, whose blood Aaron takes into the Most Holy Place for the purification ceremony, will be carried outside the camp. The animals’ hides, internal organs, and dung are all to be burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man who burns them must wash his clothes and bathe himself in water before returning to the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “On the tenth day of the appointed month in early autumn, you must deny yourselves. Neither native-born Israelites nor foreigners living among you may do any kind of work. This is a permanent law for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day offerings of purification will be made for you, and you will be purified in the Lord’s presence from all your sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be a Sabbath day of complete rest for you, and you must deny yourselves. This is a permanent law for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In future generations, the purification ceremony will be performed by the priest who has been anointed and ordained to serve as high priest in place of his ancestor Aaron. He will put on the holy linen garments
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and purify the Most Holy Place, the Tabernacle, the altar, the priests, and the entire congregation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is a permanent law for you, to purify the people of Israel from their sins, making them right with the Lord once each year.”
Moses followed all these instructions exactly as the Lord had commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to Aaron and his sons and all the people of Israel. This is what the Lord has commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If any native Israelite sacrifices a bull or a lamb or a goat anywhere inside or outside the camp
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: instead of bringing it to the entrance of the Tabernacle to present it as an offering to the Lord, that person will be as guilty as a murderer. Such a person has shed blood and will be cut off from the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The purpose of this rule is to stop the Israelites from sacrificing animals in the open fields. It will ensure that they bring their sacrifices to the priest at the entrance of the Tabernacle, so he can present them to the Lord as peace offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priest will be able to splatter the blood against the Lord’s altar at the entrance of the Tabernacle, and he will burn the fat as a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people must no longer be unfaithful to the Lord by offering sacrifices to the goat idols. This is a permanent law for them, to be observed from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give them this command as well. If any native Israelite or foreigner living among you offers a burnt offering or a sacrifice
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but does not bring it to the entrance of the Tabernacle to offer it to the Lord, that person will be cut off from the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And if any native Israelite or foreigner living among you eats or drinks blood in any form, I will turn against that person and cut him off from the community of your people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for the life of the body is in its blood. I have given you the blood on the altar to purify you, making you right with the Lord. It is the blood, given in exchange for a life, that makes purification possible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why I have said to the people of Israel, ‘You must never eat or drink blood—neither you nor the foreigners living among you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And if any native Israelite or foreigner living among you goes hunting and kills an animal or bird that is approved for eating, he must drain its blood and cover it with earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The life of every creature is in its blood. That is why I have said to the people of Israel, ‘You must never eat or drink blood, for the life of any creature is in its blood.’ So whoever consumes blood will be cut off from the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And if any native-born Israelites or foreigners eat the meat of an animal that died naturally or was torn up by wild animals, they must wash their clothes and bathe themselves in water. They will remain ceremonially unclean until evening, but then they will be clean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if they do not wash their clothes and bathe themselves, they will be punished for their sin.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So do not act like the people in Egypt, where you used to live, or like the people of Canaan, where I am taking you. You must not imitate their way of life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must obey all my regulations and be careful to obey my decrees, for I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you obey my decrees and my regulations, you will find life through them. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must never have sexual relations with a close relative, for I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not violate your father by having sexual relations with your mother. She is your mother; you must not have sexual relations with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with any of your father’s wives, for this would violate your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your sister or half sister, whether she is your father’s daughter or your mother’s daughter, whether she was born into your household or someone else’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your granddaughter, whether she is your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter, for this would violate yourself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your stepsister, the daughter of any of your father’s wives, for she is your sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your father’s sister, for she is your father’s close relative.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your mother’s sister, for she is your mother’s close relative.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not violate your uncle, your father’s brother, by having sexual relations with his wife, for she is your aunt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your daughter-in-law; she is your son’s wife, so you must not have sexual relations with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your brother’s wife, for this would violate your brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with both a woman and her daughter. And do not take her granddaughter, whether her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter, and have sexual relations with her. They are close relatives, and this would be a wicked act.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “While your wife is living, do not marry her sister and have sexual relations with her, for they would be rivals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with a woman during her period of menstrual impurity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not defile yourself by having sexual intercourse with your neighbor’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not permit any of your children to be offered as a sacrifice to Molech, for you must not bring shame on the name of your God. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not practice homosexuality, having sex with another man as with a woman. It is a detestable sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “A man must not defile himself by having sex with an animal. And a woman must not offer herself to a male animal to have intercourse with it. This is a perverse act.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not defile yourselves in any of these ways, for the people I am driving out before you have defiled themselves in all these ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the entire land has become defiled, I am punishing the people who live there. I will cause the land to vomit them out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must obey all my decrees and regulations. You must not commit any of these detestable sins. This applies both to native-born Israelites and to the foreigners living among you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All these detestable activities are practiced by the people of the land where I am taking you, and this is how the land has become defiled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So do not defile the land and give it a reason to vomit you out, as it will vomit out the people who live there now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever commits any of these detestable sins will be cut off from the community of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So obey my instructions, and do not defile yourselves by committing any of these detestable practices that were committed by the people who lived in the land before you. I am the Lord your God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord also said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the entire community of Israel. You must be holy because I, the Lord your God, am holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Each of you must show great respect for your mother and father, and you must always observe my Sabbath days of rest. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not put your trust in idols or make metal images of gods for yourselves. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you sacrifice a peace offering to the Lord, offer it properly so you will be accepted by God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sacrifice must be eaten on the same day you offer it or on the next day. Whatever is left over until the third day must be completely burned up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any of the sacrifice is eaten on the third day, it will be contaminated, and I will not accept it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who eats it on the third day will be punished for defiling what is holy to the Lord and will be cut off from the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you harvest the crops of your land, do not harvest the grain along the edges of your fields, and do not pick up what the harvesters drop.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is the same with your grape crop—do not strip every last bunch of grapes from the vines, and do not pick up the grapes that fall to the ground. Leave them for the poor and the foreigners living among you. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do not steal.
“Do not deceive or cheat one another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not bring shame on the name of your God by using it to swear falsely. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do not defraud or rob your neighbor.
“Do not make your hired workers wait until the next day to receive their pay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not insult the deaf or cause the blind to stumble. You must fear your God; I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not twist justice in legal matters by favoring the poor or being partial to the rich and powerful. Always judge people fairly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do not spread slanderous gossip among your people.
“Do not stand idly by when your neighbor’s life is threatened. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not nurse hatred in your heart for any of your relatives. Confront people directly so you will not be held guilty for their sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not seek revenge or bear a grudge against a fellow Israelite, but love your neighbor as yourself. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You must obey all my decrees.
“Do not mate two different kinds of animals. Do not plant your field with two different kinds of seed. Do not wear clothing woven from two different kinds of thread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man has sex with a slave girl whose freedom has never been purchased but who is committed to become another man’s wife, he must pay full compensation to her master. But since she is not a free woman, neither the man nor the woman will be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man, however, must bring a ram as a guilt offering and present it to the Lord at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest will then purify him before the Lord with the ram of the guilt offering, and the man’s sin will be forgiven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you enter the land and plant fruit trees, leave the fruit unharvested for the first three years and consider it forbidden. Do not eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth year the entire crop must be consecrated to the Lord as a celebration of praise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, in the fifth year you may eat the fruit. If you follow this pattern, your harvest will increase. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Do not eat meat that has not been drained of its blood.
“Do not practice fortune-telling or witchcraft.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not trim off the hair on your temples or trim your beards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not cut your bodies for the dead, and do not mark your skin with tattoos. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not defile your daughter by making her a prostitute, or the land will be filled with prostitution and wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Keep my Sabbath days of rest, and show reverence toward my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not defile yourselves by turning to mediums or to those who consult the spirits of the dead. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Stand up in the presence of the elderly, and show respect for the aged. Fear your God. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not take advantage of foreigners who live among you in your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Treat them like native-born Israelites, and love them as you love yourself. Remember that you were once foreigners living in the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not use dishonest standards when measuring length, weight, or volume.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your scales and weights must be accurate. Your containers for measuring dry materials or liquids must be accurate. I am the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must be careful to keep all of my decrees and regulations by putting them into practice. I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Give the people of Israel these instructions, which apply both to native Israelites and to the foreigners living in Israel.
“If any of them offer their children as a sacrifice to Molech, they must be put to death. The people of the community must stone them to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself will turn against them and cut them off from the community, because they have defiled my sanctuary and brought shame on my holy name by offering their children to Molech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if the people of the community ignore those who offer their children to Molech and refuse to execute them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself will turn against them and their families and will cut them off from the community. This will happen to all who commit spiritual prostitution by worshiping Molech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will also turn against those who commit spiritual prostitution by putting their trust in mediums or in those who consult the spirits of the dead. I will cut them off from the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So set yourselves apart to be holy, for I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep all my decrees by putting them into practice, for I am the Lord who makes you holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Anyone who dishonors father or mother must be put to death. Such a person is guilty of a capital offense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man commits adultery with his neighbor’s wife, both the man and the woman who have committed adultery must be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man violates his father by having sex with one of his father’s wives, both the man and the woman must be put to death, for they are guilty of a capital offense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man has sex with his daughter-in-law, both must be put to death. They have committed a perverse act and are guilty of a capital offense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man practices homosexuality, having sex with another man as with a woman, both men have committed a detestable act. They must both be put to death, for they are guilty of a capital offense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man marries both a woman and her mother, he has committed a wicked act. The man and both women must be burned to death to wipe out such wickedness from among you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man has sex with an animal, he must be put to death, and the animal must be killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a woman presents herself to a male animal to have intercourse with it, she and the animal must both be put to death. You must kill both, for they are guilty of a capital offense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man marries his sister, the daughter of either his father or his mother, and they have sexual relations, it is a shameful disgrace. They must be publicly cut off from the community. Since the man has violated his sister, he will be punished for his sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man has sexual relations with a woman during her menstrual period, both of them must be cut off from the community, for together they have exposed the source of her blood flow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not have sexual relations with your aunt, whether your mother’s sister or your father’s sister. This would dishonor a close relative. Both parties are guilty and will be punished for their sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man has sex with his uncle’s wife, he has violated his uncle. Both the man and woman will be punished for their sin, and they will die childless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a man marries his brother’s wife, it is an act of impurity. He has violated his brother, and the guilty couple will remain childless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must keep all my decrees and regulations by putting them into practice; otherwise the land to which I am bringing you as your new home will vomit you out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not live according to the customs of the people I am driving out before you. It is because they do these shameful things that I detest them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I have promised you, ‘You will possess their land because I will give it to you as your possession—a land flowing with milk and honey.’ I am the Lord your God, who has set you apart from all other people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must therefore make a distinction between ceremonially clean and unclean animals, and between clean and unclean birds. You must not defile yourselves by eating any unclean animal or bird or creature that scurries along the ground. I have identified them as being unclean for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must be holy because I, the Lord, am holy. I have set you apart from all other people to be my very own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Men and women among you who act as mediums or who consult the spirits of the dead must be put to death by stoning. They are guilty of a capital offense.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Moses, “Give the following instructions to the priests, the descendants of Aaron.
“A priest must not make himself ceremonially unclean by touching the dead body of a relative.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The only exceptions are his closest relatives—his mother or father, son or daughter, brother,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or his virgin sister who depends on him because she has no husband.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a priest must not defile himself and make himself unclean for someone who is related to him only by marriage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The priests must not shave their heads or trim their beards or cut their bodies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They must be set apart as holy to their God and must never bring shame on the name of God. They must be holy, for they are the ones who present the special gifts to the Lord, gifts of food for their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Priests may not marry a woman defiled by prostitution, and they may not marry a woman who is divorced from her husband, for the priests are set apart as holy to their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must treat them as holy because they offer up food to your God. You must consider them holy because I, the Lord, am holy, and I make you holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If a priest’s daughter defiles herself by becoming a prostitute, she also defiles her father’s holiness, and she must be burned to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The high priest has the highest rank of all the priests. The anointing oil has been poured on his head, and he has been ordained to wear the priestly garments. He must never leave his hair uncombed or tear his clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He must not defile himself by going near a dead body. He may not make himself ceremonially unclean even for his father or mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He must not defile the sanctuary of his God by leaving it to attend to a dead person, for he has been made holy by the anointing oil of his God. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The high priest may marry only a virgin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He may not marry a widow, a woman who is divorced, or a woman who has defiled herself by prostitution. She must be a virgin from his own clan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that he will not dishonor his descendants among his clan, for I am the Lord who makes him holy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to Aaron: In all future generations, none of your descendants who has any defect will qualify to offer food to his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one who has a defect qualifies, whether he is blind, lame, disfigured, deformed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or has a broken foot or arm,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or is hunchbacked or dwarfed, or has a defective eye, or skin sores or scabs, or damaged testicles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No descendant of Aaron who has a defect may approach the altar to present special gifts to the Lord. Since he has a defect, he may not approach the altar to offer food to his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, he may eat from the food offered to God, including the holy offerings and the most holy offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet because of his physical defect, he may not enter the room behind the inner curtain or approach the altar, for this would defile my holy places. I am the Lord who makes them holy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses gave these instructions to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell Aaron and his sons to be very careful with the sacred gifts that the Israelites set apart for me, so they do not bring shame on my holy name. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give them the following instructions.
“In all future generations, if any of your descendants is ceremonially unclean when he approaches the sacred offerings that the people of Israel consecrate to the Lord, he must be cut off from my presence. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If any of Aaron’s descendants has a skin disease or any kind of discharge that makes him ceremonially unclean, he may not eat from the sacred offerings until he has been pronounced clean. He also becomes unclean by touching a corpse, or by having an emission of semen,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or by touching a small animal that is unclean, or by touching someone who is ceremonially unclean for any reason.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man who is defiled in any of these ways will remain unclean until evening. He may not eat from the sacred offerings until he has bathed himself in water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sun goes down, he will be ceremonially clean again and may eat from the sacred offerings, for this is his food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He may not eat an animal that has died a natural death or has been torn apart by wild animals, for this would defile him. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The priests must follow my instructions carefully. Otherwise they will be punished for their sin and will die for violating my instructions. I am the Lord who makes them holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No one outside a priest’s family may eat the sacred offerings. Even guests and hired workers in a priest’s home are not allowed to eat them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, if the priest buys a slave for himself, the slave may eat from the sacred offerings. And if his slaves have children, they also may share his food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a priest’s daughter marries someone outside the priestly family, she may no longer eat the sacred offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if she becomes a widow or is divorced and has no children to support her, and she returns to live in her father’s home as in her youth, she may eat her father’s food again. Otherwise, no one outside a priest’s family may eat the sacred offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Any such person who eats the sacred offerings without realizing it must pay the priest for the amount eaten, plus an additional 20 percent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests must not let the Israelites defile the sacred offerings brought to the Lord
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: by allowing unauthorized people to eat them. This would bring guilt upon them and require them to pay compensation. I am the Lord who makes them holy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Give Aaron and his sons and all the Israelites these instructions, which apply both to native Israelites and to the foreigners living among you.
“If you present a gift as a burnt offering to the Lord, whether it is to fulfill a vow or is a voluntary offering,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you will be accepted only if your offering is a male animal with no defects. It may be a bull, a ram, or a male goat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not present an animal with defects, because the Lord will not accept it on your behalf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you present a peace offering to the Lord from the herd or the flock, whether it is to fulfill a vow or is a voluntary offering, you must offer a perfect animal. It may have no defect of any kind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must not offer an animal that is blind, crippled, or injured, or that has a wart, a skin sore, or scabs. Such animals must never be offered on the altar as special gifts to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a bull or lamb has a leg that is too long or too short, it may be offered as a voluntary offering, but it may not be offered to fulfill a vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If an animal has damaged testicles or is castrated, you may not offer it to the Lord. You must never do this in your own land,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you must not accept such an animal from foreigners and then offer it as a sacrifice to your God. Such animals will not be accepted on your behalf, for they are mutilated or defective.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When a calf or lamb or goat is born, it must be left with its mother for seven days. From the eighth day on, it will be acceptable as a special gift to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must not slaughter a mother animal and her offspring on the same day, whether from the herd or the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you bring a thanksgiving offering to the Lord, sacrifice it properly so you will be accepted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eat the entire sacrificial animal on the day it is presented. Do not leave any of it until the next morning. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must faithfully keep all my commands by putting them into practice, for I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not bring shame on my holy name, for I will display my holiness among the people of Israel. I am the Lord who makes you holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was I who rescued you from the land of Egypt, that I might be your God. I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. These are the Lord’s appointed festivals, which you are to proclaim as official days for holy assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have six days each week for your ordinary work, but the seventh day is a Sabbath day of complete rest, an official day for holy assembly. It is the Lord’s Sabbath day, and it must be observed wherever you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In addition to the Sabbath, these are the Lord’s appointed festivals, the official days for holy assembly that are to be celebrated at their proper times each year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord’s Passover begins at sundown on the fourteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the next day, the fifteenth day of the month, you must begin celebrating the Festival of Unleavened Bread. This festival to the Lord continues for seven days, and during that time the bread you eat must be made without yeast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day of the festival, all the people must stop their ordinary work and observe an official day for holy assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you must present special gifts to the Lord. On the seventh day the people must again stop all their ordinary work to observe an official day for holy assembly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. When you enter the land I am giving you and you harvest its first crops, bring the priest a bundle of grain from the first cutting of your grain harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day after the Sabbath, the priest will lift it up before the Lord so it may be accepted on your behalf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that same day you must sacrifice a one-year-old male lamb with no defects as a burnt offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With it you must present a grain offering consisting of four quarts of choice flour moistened with olive oil. It will be a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the Lord. You must also offer one quart of wine as a liquid offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not eat any bread or roasted grain or fresh kernels on that day until you bring this offering to your God. This is a permanent law for you, and it must be observed from generation to generation wherever you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “From the day after the Sabbath—the day you bring the bundle of grain to be lifted up as a special offering—count off seven full weeks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep counting until the day after the seventh Sabbath, fifty days later. Then present an offering of new grain to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From wherever you live, bring two loaves of bread to be lifted up before the Lord as a special offering. Make these loaves from four quarts of choice flour, and bake them with yeast. They will be an offering to the Lord from the first of your crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Along with the bread, present seven one-year-old male lambs with no defects, one young bull, and two rams as burnt offerings to the Lord. These burnt offerings, together with the grain offerings and liquid offerings, will be a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you must offer one male goat as a sin offering and two one-year-old male lambs as a peace offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The priest will lift up the two lambs as a special offering to the Lord, together with the loaves representing the first of your crops. These offerings, which are holy to the Lord, belong to the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day will be proclaimed an official day for holy assembly, a day on which you do no ordinary work. This is a permanent law for you, and it must be observed from generation to generation wherever you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you harvest the crops of your land, do not harvest the grain along the edges of your fields, and do not pick up what the harvesters drop. Leave it for the poor and the foreigners living among you. I am the Lord your God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. On the first day of the appointed month in early autumn, you are to observe a day of complete rest. It will be an official day for holy assembly, a day commemorated with loud blasts of a trumpet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must do no ordinary work on that day. Instead, you are to present special gifts to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be careful to celebrate the Day of Atonement on the tenth day of that same month—nine days after the Festival of Trumpets. You must observe it as an official day for holy assembly, a day to deny yourselves and present special gifts to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do no work during that entire day because it is the Day of Atonement, when offerings of purification are made for you, making you right with the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All who do not deny themselves that day will be cut off from God’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will destroy anyone among you who does any work on that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must not do any work at all! This is a permanent law for you, and it must be observed from generation to generation wherever you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This will be a Sabbath day of complete rest for you, and on that day you must deny yourselves. This day of rest will begin at sundown on the ninth day of the month and extend until sundown on the tenth day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. Begin celebrating the Festival of Shelters on the fifteenth day of the appointed month—five days after the Day of Atonement. This festival to the Lord will last for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day of the festival you must proclaim an official day for holy assembly, when you do no ordinary work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you must present special gifts to the Lord. The eighth day is another holy day on which you present your special gifts to the Lord. This will be a solemn occasion, and no ordinary work may be done that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (“These are the Lord’s appointed festivals. Celebrate them each year as official days for holy assembly by presenting special gifts to the Lord—burnt offerings, grain offerings, sacrifices, and liquid offerings—each on its proper day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These festivals must be observed in addition to the Lord’s regular Sabbath days, and the offerings are in addition to your personal gifts, the offerings you give to fulfill your vows, and the voluntary offerings you present to the Lord.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Remember that this seven-day festival to the Lord—the Festival of Shelters—begins on the fifteenth day of the appointed month, after you have harvested all the produce of the land. The first day and the eighth day of the festival will be days of complete rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day gather branches from magnificent trees—palm fronds, boughs from leafy trees, and willows that grow by the streams. Then celebrate with joy before the Lord your God for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must observe this festival to the Lord for seven days every year. This is a permanent law for you, and it must be observed in the appointed month from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you must live outside in little shelters. All native-born Israelites must live in shelters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This will remind each new generation of Israelites that I made their ancestors live in shelters when I rescued them from the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses gave the Israelites these instructions regarding the annual festivals of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Command the people of Israel to bring you pure oil of pressed olives for the light, to keep the lamps burning continually.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the lampstand that stands in the Tabernacle, in front of the inner curtain that shields the Ark of the Covenant. Aaron must keep the lamps burning in the Lord’s presence all night. This is a permanent law for you, and it must be observed from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron and the priests must tend the lamps on the pure gold lampstand continually in the Lord’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must bake twelve flat loaves of bread from choice flour, using four quarts of flour for each loaf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Place the bread before the Lord on the pure gold table, and arrange the loaves in two stacks, with six loaves in each stack.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put some pure frankincense near each stack to serve as a representative offering, a special gift presented to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every Sabbath day this bread must be laid out before the Lord as a gift from the Israelites; it is an ongoing expression of the eternal covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The loaves of bread will belong to Aaron and his descendants, who must eat them in a sacred place, for they are most holy. It is the permanent right of the priests to claim this portion of the special gifts presented to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day a man who had an Israelite mother and an Egyptian father came out of his tent and got into a fight with one of the Israelite men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the fight, this son of an Israelite woman blasphemed the Name of the Lord with a curse. So the man was brought to Moses for judgment. His mother was Shelomith, the daughter of Dibri of the tribe of Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They kept the man in custody until the Lord’s will in the matter should become clear to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take the blasphemer outside the camp, and tell all those who heard the curse to lay their hands on his head. Then let the entire community stone him to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to the people of Israel: Those who curse their God will be punished for their sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who blasphemes the Name of the Lord must be stoned to death by the whole community of Israel. Any native-born Israelite or foreigner among you who blasphemes the Name of the Lord must be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Anyone who takes another person’s life must be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Anyone who kills another person’s animal must pay for it in full—a live animal for the animal that was killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Anyone who injures another person must be dealt with according to the injury inflicted—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a fracture for a fracture, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth. Whatever anyone does to injure another person must be paid back in kind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Whoever kills an animal must pay for it in full, but whoever kills another person must be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This same standard applies both to native-born Israelites and to the foreigners living among you. I am the Lord your God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses gave all these instructions to the Israelites, they took the blasphemer outside the camp and stoned him to death. The Israelites did just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Moses was on Mount Sinai, the Lord said to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. When you have entered the land I am giving you, the land itself must observe a Sabbath rest before the Lord every seventh year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For six years you may plant your fields and prune your vineyards and harvest your crops,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but during the seventh year the land must have a Sabbath year of complete rest. It is the Lord’s Sabbath. Do not plant your fields or prune your vineyards during that year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And don’t store away the crops that grow on their own or gather the grapes from your unpruned vines. The land must have a year of complete rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you may eat whatever the land produces on its own during its Sabbath. This applies to you, your male and female servants, your hired workers, and the temporary residents who live with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your livestock and the wild animals in your land will also be allowed to eat what the land produces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In addition, you must count off seven Sabbath years, seven sets of seven years, adding up to forty-nine years in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then on the Day of Atonement in the fiftieth year, blow the ram’s horn loud and long throughout the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Set this year apart as holy, a time to proclaim freedom throughout the land for all who live there. It will be a jubilee year for you, when each of you may return to the land that belonged to your ancestors and return to your own clan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This fiftieth year will be a jubilee for you. During that year you must not plant your fields or store away any of the crops that grow on their own, and don’t gather the grapes from your unpruned vines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be a jubilee year for you, and you must keep it holy. But you may eat whatever the land produces on its own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the Year of Jubilee each of you may return to the land that belonged to your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you make an agreement with your neighbor to buy or sell property, you must not take advantage of each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you buy land from your neighbor, the price you pay must be based on the number of years since the last jubilee. The seller must set the price by taking into account the number of years remaining until the next Year of Jubilee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The more years until the next jubilee, the higher the price; the fewer years, the lower the price. After all, the person selling the land is actually selling you a certain number of harvests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Show your fear of God by not taking advantage of each other. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you want to live securely in the land, follow my decrees and obey my regulations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the land will yield large crops, and you will eat your fill and live securely in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you might ask, ‘What will we eat during the seventh year, since we are not allowed to plant or harvest crops that year?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be assured that I will send my blessing for you in the sixth year, so the land will produce a crop large enough for three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you plant your fields in the eighth year, you will still be eating from the large crop of the sixth year. In fact, you will still be eating from that large crop when the new crop is harvested in the ninth year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The land must never be sold on a permanent basis, for the land belongs to me. You are only foreigners and tenant farmers working for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “With every purchase of land you must grant the seller the right to buy it back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If one of your fellow Israelites falls into poverty and is forced to sell some family land, then a close relative should buy it back for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If there is no close relative to buy the land, but the person who sold it gets enough money to buy it back,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he then has the right to redeem it from the one who bought it. The price of the land will be discounted according to the number of years until the next Year of Jubilee. In this way the original owner can then return to the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the original owner cannot afford to buy back the land, it will remain with the new owner until the next Year of Jubilee. In the jubilee year, the land must be returned to the original owners so they can return to their family land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Anyone who sells a house inside a walled town has the right to buy it back for a full year after its sale. During that year, the seller retains the right to buy it back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if it is not bought back within a year, the sale of the house within the walled town cannot be reversed. It will become the permanent property of the buyer. It will not be returned to the original owner in the Year of Jubilee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a house in a village—a settlement without fortified walls—will be treated like property in the countryside. Such a house may be bought back at any time, and it must be returned to the original owner in the Year of Jubilee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Levites always have the right to buy back a house they have sold within the towns allotted to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And any property that is sold by the Levites—all houses within the Levitical towns—must be returned in the Year of Jubilee. After all, the houses in the towns reserved for the Levites are the only property they own in all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The open pastureland around the Levitical towns may never be sold. It is their permanent possession.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If one of your fellow Israelites falls into poverty and cannot support himself, support him as you would a foreigner or a temporary resident and allow him to live with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not charge interest or make a profit at his expense. Instead, show your fear of God by letting him live with you as your relative.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember, do not charge interest on money you lend him or make a profit on food you sell him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If one of your fellow Israelites falls into poverty and is forced to sell himself to you, do not treat him as a slave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Treat him instead as a hired worker or as a temporary resident who lives with you, and he will serve you only until the Year of Jubilee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time he and his children will no longer be obligated to you, and they will return to their clans and go back to the land originally allotted to their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel are my servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt, so they must never be sold as slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Show your fear of God by not treating them harshly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “However, you may purchase male and female slaves from among the nations around you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may also purchase the children of temporary residents who live among you, including those who have been born in your land. You may treat them as your property,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: passing them on to your children as a permanent inheritance. You may treat them as slaves, but you must never treat your fellow Israelites this way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Suppose a foreigner or temporary resident becomes rich while living among you. If any of your fellow Israelites fall into poverty and are forced to sell themselves to such a foreigner or to a member of his family,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they still retain the right to be bought back, even after they have been purchased. They may be bought back by a brother,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: an uncle, or a cousin. In fact, anyone from the extended family may buy them back. They may also redeem themselves if they have prospered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will negotiate the price of their freedom with the person who bought them. The price will be based on the number of years from the time they were sold until the next Year of Jubilee—whatever it would cost to hire a worker for that period of time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If many years still remain until the jubilee, they will repay the proper proportion of what they received when they sold themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If only a few years remain until the Year of Jubilee, they will repay a small amount for their redemption.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The foreigner must treat them as workers hired on a yearly basis. You must not allow a foreigner to treat any of your fellow Israelites harshly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any Israelites have not been bought back by the time the Year of Jubilee arrives, they and their children must be set free at that time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the people of Israel belong to me. They are my servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not make idols or set up carved images, or sacred pillars, or sculptured stones in your land so you may worship them. I am the Lord your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must keep my Sabbath days of rest and show reverence for my sanctuary. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If you follow my decrees and are careful to obey my commands,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send you the seasonal rains. The land will then yield its crops, and the trees of the field will produce their fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your threshing season will overlap with the grape harvest, and your grape harvest will overlap with the season of planting grain. You will eat your fill and live securely in your own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will give you peace in the land, and you will be able to sleep with no cause for fear. I will rid the land of wild animals and keep your enemies out of your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, you will chase down your enemies and slaughter them with your swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Five of you will chase a hundred, and a hundred of you will chase ten thousand! All your enemies will fall beneath your sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will look favorably upon you, making you fertile and multiplying your people. And I will fulfill my covenant with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will have such a surplus of crops that you will need to clear out the old grain to make room for the new harvest!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will live among you, and I will not despise you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will walk among you; I will be your God, and you will be my people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt so you would no longer be their slaves. I broke the yoke of slavery from your neck so you can walk with your heads held high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “However, if you do not listen to me or obey all these commands,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and if you break my covenant by rejecting my decrees, treating my regulations with contempt, and refusing to obey my commands,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish you. I will bring sudden terrors upon you—wasting diseases and burning fevers that will cause your eyes to fail and your life to ebb away. You will plant your crops in vain because your enemies will eat them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will turn against you, and you will be defeated by your enemies. Those who hate you will rule over you, and you will run even when no one is chasing you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And if, in spite of all this, you still disobey me, I will punish you seven times over for your sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will break your proud spirit by making the skies as unyielding as iron and the earth as hard as bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All your work will be for nothing, for your land will yield no crops, and your trees will bear no fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If even then you remain hostile toward me and refuse to obey me, I will inflict disaster on you seven times over for your sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send wild animals that will rob you of your children and destroy your livestock. Your numbers will dwindle, and your roads will be deserted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And if you fail to learn the lesson and continue your hostility toward me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I myself will be hostile toward you. I will personally strike you with calamity seven times over for your sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send armies against you to carry out the curse of the covenant you have broken. When you run to your towns for safety, I will send a plague to destroy you there, and you will be handed over to your enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will destroy your food supply, so that ten women will need only one oven to bake bread for their families. They will ration your food by weight, and though you have food to eat, you will not be satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If in spite of all this you still refuse to listen and still remain hostile toward me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will give full vent to my hostility. I myself will punish you seven times over for your sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will eat the flesh of your own sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will destroy your pagan shrines and knock down your places of worship. I will leave your lifeless corpses piled on top of your lifeless idols, and I will despise you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make your cities desolate and destroy your places of pagan worship. I will take no pleasure in your offerings that should be a pleasing aroma to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, I myself will devastate your land, and your enemies who come to occupy it will be appalled at what they see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will scatter you among the nations and bring out my sword against you. Your land will become desolate, and your cities will lie in ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then at last the land will enjoy its neglected Sabbath years as it lies desolate while you are in exile in the land of your enemies. Then the land will finally rest and enjoy the Sabbaths it missed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As long as the land lies in ruins, it will enjoy the rest you never allowed it to take every seventh year while you lived in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And for those of you who survive, I will demoralize you in the land of your enemies. You will live in such fear that the sound of a leaf driven by the wind will send you fleeing. You will run as though fleeing from a sword, and you will fall even when no one pursues you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Though no one is chasing you, you will stumble over each other as though fleeing from a sword. You will have no power to stand up against your enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will die among the foreign nations and be devoured in the land of your enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those of you who survive will waste away in your enemies’ lands because of their sins and the sins of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But at last my people will confess their sins and the sins of their ancestors for betraying me and being hostile toward me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I have turned their hostility back on them and brought them to the land of their enemies, then at last their stubborn hearts will be humbled, and they will pay for their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will remember my covenant with Jacob and my covenant with Isaac and my covenant with Abraham, and I will remember the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the land must be abandoned to enjoy its years of Sabbath rest as it lies deserted. At last the people will pay for their sins, for they have continually rejected my regulations and despised my decrees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But despite all this, I will not utterly reject or despise them while they are in exile in the land of their enemies. I will not cancel my covenant with them by wiping them out, for I am the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For their sakes I will remember my ancient covenant with their ancestors, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt in the sight of all the nations, that I might be their God. I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the decrees, regulations, and instructions that the Lord gave through Moses on Mount Sinai as evidence of the relationship between himself and the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. If anyone makes a special vow to dedicate someone to the Lord by paying the value of that person,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: here is the scale of values to be used. A man between the ages of twenty and sixty is valued at fifty shekels of silver, as measured by the sanctuary shekel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A woman of that age is valued at thirty shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A boy between the ages of five and twenty is valued at twenty shekels of silver; a girl of that age is valued at ten shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A boy between the ages of one month and five years is valued at five shekels of silver; a girl of that age is valued at three shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man older than sixty is valued at fifteen shekels of silver; a woman of that age is valued at ten shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you desire to make such a vow but cannot afford to pay the required amount, take the person to the priest. He will determine the amount for you to pay based on what you can afford.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If your vow involves giving an animal that is acceptable as an offering to the Lord, any gift to the Lord will be considered holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may not exchange or substitute it for another animal—neither a good animal for a bad one nor a bad animal for a good one. But if you do exchange one animal for another, then both the original animal and its substitute will be considered holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If your vow involves an unclean animal—one that is not acceptable as an offering to the Lord—then you must bring the animal to the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will assess its value, and his assessment will be final, whether high or low.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you want to buy back the animal, you must pay the value set by the priest, plus 20 percent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If someone dedicates a house to the Lord, the priest will come to assess its value. The priest’s assessment will be final, whether high or low.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the person who dedicated the house wants to buy it back, he must pay the value set by the priest, plus 20 percent. Then the house will again be his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If someone dedicates to the Lord a piece of his family property, its value will be assessed according to the amount of seed required to plant it—fifty shekels of silver for a field planted with five bushels of barley seed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the field is dedicated to the Lord in the Year of Jubilee, then the entire assessment will apply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the field is dedicated after the Year of Jubilee, the priest will assess the land’s value in proportion to the number of years left until the next Year of Jubilee. Its assessed value is reduced each year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the person who dedicated the field wants to buy it back, he must pay the value set by the priest, plus 20 percent. Then the field will again be legally his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if he does not want to buy it back, and it is sold to someone else, the field can no longer be bought back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the field is released in the Year of Jubilee, it will be holy, a field specially set apart for the Lord. It will become the property of the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If someone dedicates to the Lord a field he has purchased but which is not part of his family property,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the priest will assess its value based on the number of years left until the next Year of Jubilee. On that day he must give the assessed value of the land as a sacred donation to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the Year of Jubilee the field must be returned to the person from whom he purchased it, the one who inherited it as family property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (All the payments must be measured by the weight of the sanctuary shekel, which equals twenty gerahs.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You may not dedicate a firstborn animal to the Lord, for the firstborn of your cattle, sheep, and goats already belong to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, you may buy back the firstborn of a ceremonially unclean animal by paying the priest’s assessment of its worth, plus 20 percent. If you do not buy it back, the priest will sell it at its assessed value.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “However, anything specially set apart for the Lord—whether a person, an animal, or family property—must never be sold or bought back. Anything devoted in this way has been set apart as holy, and it belongs to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No person specially set apart for destruction may be bought back. Such a person must be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “One-tenth of the produce of the land, whether grain from the fields or fruit from the trees, belongs to the Lord and must be set apart to him as holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you want to buy back the Lord’s tenth of the grain or fruit, you must pay its value, plus 20 percent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Count off every tenth animal from your herds and flocks and set them apart for the Lord as holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may not pick and choose between good and bad animals, and you may not substitute one for another. But if you do exchange one animal for another, then both the original animal and its substitute will be considered holy and cannot be bought back.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the commands that the Lord gave through Moses on Mount Sinai for the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator
